availability.p: All research and writing of Civil War Governors of Kentucky Digital Documentary Edition annotations was undertaken by project staff, volunteers, and interns. Each record contains citations to relevant primary and secondary source material. All annotations are copyright Kentucky Historical Society, and should be referenced as such in any published work.

seriesStmt.title: Civil War Governors of Kentucky Digital Documentary Edition

body.p: A Kentucky lawyer, farmer, and politician. Pursued education in the law. Managed the family land and farm. Married to Evelyn Byrd Woodson. Father of William Creighton Woodson, Sarah Woodson, Anna Meade Woodson, and Jessamine Byrd Woodson. Owned nineteen enslaved persons in 1850 and twelve in 1860. Member of the Whig Party and Republican Party. Represented Jessamine County as a member of the Kentucky House of Representatives from 1835 to 1837 and in 1840. Served as a member of the Kentucky Senate from 1842 to 1846 and 1853 to 1857. Served as a member of the Union Executive Committee of Kentucky in 1865.

bibl.p: KYR-0002-022-0001; Bennett H. Young, A History of Jessamine County, Kentucky, from its Earliest Settlement to 1898 (Louisville: Courier-Journal Job Printing Co., 1898), 79 and 213-215; “Union State Convention at Frankfort,” The Commonwealth (Frankfort, Ky.), January 6, 1865; “Tucker Woodson,” (http://politicalgraveyard.com/bio/woodside-woodville.html#715.72.58) (accessed February 1, 2017); Seventh Manuscript Census of the United States (1850), Population Schedules, Kentucky, Jessamine County, District No 2; Seventh Manuscript Census of the United States (1850), Slave Schedules, Kentucky, Jessamine County, District No 2; Eighth Manuscript Census of the United States (1860), Population Schedules, Kentucky, Jessamine County, p. 74; Eighth Manuscript Census of the United States (1860), Slave Schedules, Kentucky, Jessamine County, p. 18.
